title: How to finish undergrad and get my bachelors degree in less than 4 years - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, you can finish undergrad and get your bachelor's degree in less than four calendar years. Here's how. (1) Take AP or IB classes in high school, score well on the tests, and you can get college credits. (2) If you can, do "dual enrollment" where you take some college classes while in high school. Public Community Colleges are good options for this. Some four year colleges will also permit dual enrollment. (3) If you have unusual life experience, or prior military experience, sit for some of the 33 available CLEP tests. You may get some course credits that way. (4) Plan to stay in your college town and take Summer courses. This is especially worthwhile if you've had to sign a 12-month lease on your living space. (University-affiliated housing may only require a semester or school-year lease agreement.) By actually using the place year round, you're getting full advantage from your rent. (5) If you do a semester abroad, be absolutely certain that all of your credits will count. Some schools do not give full credit for courses taught through other colleges' semester abroad programs. If you already have a lot of transfer credits or credits from testing (AP, IB, or CLEP) your semester abroad credits may not count. Be sure you know how many externally awarded credits you can count towards your diploma. Also be sure you know whether externally awarded credits can count towards your major. Some schools will only allow them to count for area distribution requirements or electives.

Yes. Use College Level Examination Program (CLEP) exams to test out of your first 2 years of coursework. Each exam costs $85 and you can sometimes take up to 20 exams that apply to electives in your degree. That cuts your Bachelor’s degree from 4 years into 2 years. You need 120 credits to graduate. You’ve earned 60 credits with CLEP. Your remaining 60 credits (generally the requirements for your major) don’t have to be full time either. Some schools offer summer classes and allow you to bump your schedule. Instead of doing 15 credit hours a semester, and studying for 2 semesters a year, take 18 credits (one extra course) in the fall and winter, and then take 5 courses in the summer. Your degree looks like this: Semester 1 (Sep - Dec): CLEP Exams (60 credits so far)Semester 2 (Jan - Apr): 18 credits (78 credits so far)Summer: 15 credits (93 credits so far)Semester 3: 18 (111 credits so far)Semester 4: 9 credits (120 credits)Because of your summer classes, you end up only needing 3 courses in your final semester. Additional sources of credit include: Prior Learning and RecognitionChallenge Exams (write the exam - if you pass, you get the credit. Some schools use your score on the exam as your letter grade)American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Language exams - you can get up to 12 upper-level (3rd year/4th year credits) in a foreign language by passing an exam in a language you’ve self-studiedGood luck.

Most U.K. degrees are 3 years. However…. in the U.K., the school A level is equivalent to a US first year of a degree. The A level is the entrance qualification for U.K. universities.You can do a 4 year Masters degree bypassing the Batchelor's degree.You can also do a 4 year sandwich Batchelor's degree, where after the second year you take a year out to study or work overseas. Or work in the U.K. you then complete your 3rd year of study in year 4.Another option is to do the Batchelor’s degree in 2 years, but graduate with the base degree without honours. Courses like a HND are degree equivalent. You can then do diplomas or other qualifications to give you honours degree equivalence. This is a good option if you have difficulty in financing your studies, as you can take time between study to work and earn money.

Accelerated courses and school all year round! Many universities in the USA offer a 7–8 week course option over the traditional 15week option. Completing 19–30 credits per semester could easily get you done in 2 years. Example I took 3 course 4 credits a peace the first block (half a semester) and then 2 4 credit course and 1 3 credit course. That semester I cleared 23 credits. Keeping that pace and or more will net you degree completion in possibly 18 months starting from 0 for a 120–124 credit degree program. Keep in mind that summer session yield two 7–8week accelerated courses.

The easiest answer is never take fewer than 18 hours during winter and also spring semesters and then go to summer school. I graduated in less than three years with a double major and it's not an unreasonable task. But always talk to your college counselor and if you don't have one get one! It saves lots of h headaches later on. Good luck

Yes, people have done it in less than 4 years, but those people were generally pretty remarkable in one or more ways. That's why most colleges will quote percentages for graduation in 4, 5, and 6 years. For normal humans, all three of those possibilities are quite real.

Meet with your academic advisor and come up with a plan of study. Take full time course loads every semester, including in the summer. Take additional courses at community colleges that can transfer. But, make sure everything you’re doing will work for you and what you can do - it probably won’t work well if you have a job or cannot afford taking full time class loads each semester.

Yes. Might involve some summer school, credit packing (taking an extra 3-credit course or two per semester) and a ton of work but it can definitely be done. Look at the degree requirements and see what you can do and when - pay attention to pre-requisite chains. If A-B-C-D must be taken in that order in subsequent semesters, then you need to make sure that you can get each one in the semester you want.
You can do that, but you will need to attend summer school classes at least two summers in order to earn enough credits to graduate in less than four years.
Probably. Some schools take advanced scores on high school courses the equivalent of a college course so you can start as a sophomore. Others will give credit for summer courses, etc.

Thanks for the A2A. Yes, you can get a bachelor's degree in three years by studying in many European countries. World top ten universities offering the year bachelor's degrees inside Oxford, Cambridge, Imperial College London, UCL, and ETH Zurich. Except for the last of these, teaching is in English (at Zurich teaching is in German in the first year and a mix of a German and English in the second and third years).
